discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. nslookup

To identify which DNS servers a computer is configured to use, a network technician should use the "nslookup" command. This command is specifically designed for querying Domain Name System (DNS) servers to obtain information about domain names, including the IP addresses of DNS servers.

The correct answer is:

C. nslookup

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The routing protocol with routes classified with an administrative distance of 110 is B. OSPF (Open Shortest Path First).

Here's a breakdown of administrative distances for common routing protocols:

BGP (Border Gateway Protocol): 20
OSPF (Open Shortest Path First): 110
EIGRP (Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol): 90
RIP (Routing Information Protocol): 120
OSPF has a default distance of 110, RIP, has a default distance of 120.

Selected Answer: B
B. OSPF (Open Shortest Path First)

OSPF routes have an administrative distance of 110.

Selected Answer: B
It's B) OSPF.

BGP== has 20
EIGRP==has 170
RIP==has 120

please correct me if I'm wrong..

OSPF is the correct answer.

comments.content: Where did you find this information? The cisco website says that RIP has a default distance of 120. OSPF has a distance of 110. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/border-gateway-protocol-bgp/15986-admin-distance.html
RIP has an administrative distance of 120. OSPF is 110.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. RIP (Routing Information Protocol)

RIP (Routing Information Protocol) is a routing protocol that uses an administrative distance of 110 for its routes. Administrative distance is a metric used to prioritize routes when multiple routing protocols are in use, and lower values indicate higher preference. RIP is a distance-vector routing protocol and is typically used in smaller networks due to its limitations.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C - SaaS, note the word delivery be understood as the app already has been created. If the question asked for app creation or development, then it would be PaaS. .

Selected Answer: C
Correct Answer: C
The main difference between SaaS and PaaS is that SaaS provides ready-to-use software applications to customers, while PaaS provides a platform for customers to develop, run, and manage their own applications.

Selected Answer: C
SaaS is a software deployment model in which a third-party provider builds applications on cloud infrastructure and makes them available to customers via the internet. PaaS focuses on Development platform and Database. It provides a framework for creating and deploying applications.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
its D because PaaS provides developers with the tools and infrastructure they need to develop, deploy, and manage applications. This includes things like computing resources, storage, databases, and development tools.

Selected Answer: D
PaaS stands for Platform as a Service. It is a cloud computing service that provides a platform for developing, deploying, and managing applications. PaaS providers typically provide the following services:

Operating system
Programming language runtime
Database
Web server
Application server

questions.question_text: Which of the following focuses on application delivery?
A network engineer is concerned about VLAN hopping happening on the network. Which of the following should the engineer do to address this concern?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
By changing the native VLAN, the attacker would not be able to deceive the switch by sending double tagging frame, because in that case the switch would drop the frame since its outer tag would have a VLAN ID (native VLAN ID) that is not the same as the access VLAN configured on the attacker port. 
Source: https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/s/blogs/a0D3i000002SKPREA4/vlan1-and-vlan-hopping-attack

Selected Answer: A
A. Configure private VLANs.

Private VLANs (PVLANs) segregate devices within the same VLAN, restricting their communication to enhance network security and isolation. To address concerns about VLAN hopping, configuring private VLANs (PVLANs) is an effective security measure. PVLANs restrict communication between devices within the same VLAN, preventing one device from "hopping" to another device's traffic within the same VLAN.

comments.content: Changing the default VLAN remains a more effective measure for preventing VLAN hopping compared to configuring private VLANs because it directly mitigates the risk of unauthorized access between VLANs caused by potential vulnerabilities or misconfigurations, providing a proactive defense strategy for overall network security. Plus due to the vague question, how do we know that the VLANs aren't already private? Answer is B.

discussion.content: Private VLANs were designed to mitigate these attacks, changing the default VLAN is a good practice but this seems more secure.
Default and Native VLAN are not the same. Default VLAN is VLAN 1 and that can't be changed.

Selected Answer: B
Double Tagging can only be exploited on switch ports configured to use native VLANs.[2]: 162  Trunk ports configured with a native VLAN don't apply a VLAN tag when sending these frames. This allows an attacker's fake VLAN tag to be read by the next switch.

So its B. Change the Native/Default VLAN

Selected Answer: B
Changing default VLAN means default attacks won't happen.

Selected Answer: B
if the admin is worried about vlan hopping, private vland have already been configured. B

Selected Answer: B
The question is about vlan hopping, not communication within vlans.

PVLANS segregate devices within a VLAN. This is not the threat vector the question is asking about.

Option B is correct.

Selected Answer: D
option D

Selected Answer: A
A. Configure private VLANs.

Private VLANs (PVLANs) are designed to enhance security by isolating ports within the same VLAN from each other, thus preventing VLAN hopping attacks. This configuration restricts communication between devices within the same VLAN, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or interference.

Selected Answer: D
D. Enable dynamic ARP inspection.

Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) is a security feature that helps prevent ARP spoofing attacks and VLAN hopping. VLAN hopping occurs when an attacker sends frames from one VLAN to another VLAN, exploiting the lack of proper VLAN separation.

Dynamic ARP Inspection helps mitigate VLAN hopping by inspecting ARP packets and ensuring that ARP requests and responses are valid within the associated VLANs. It builds a binding table that maps IP addresses to MAC addresses and VLANs, and it drops ARP packets that are inconsistent with this table.

While other options like configuring private VLANs (Option A), changing the default VLAN (Option B), and implementing ACLs (Option C) can contribute to network security, they may not specifically address VLAN hopping concerns. Enabling dynamic ARP inspection is a more targeted solution for preventing this specific type of attack.

Selected Answer: A
ChatGPT says A

Selected Answer: D
D. Enable dynamic ARP inspection.

Dynamic ARP inspection (DAI) is a security feature that can help address VLAN hopping concerns. VLAN hopping occurs when an attacker sends packets with a false VLAN ID to gain unauthorized access to frames belonging to a different VLAN.

By enabling dynamic ARP inspection, the network switches can validate ARP packets to ensure that the source MAC address and IP address match. If an ARP reply is received on an interface belonging to a different VLAN than what is expected, the switch can drop or block the packet, thus preventing potential VLAN hopping attacks.

Selected Answer: B
The status message “GigabitEthernet0/9 is down, line protocol is down (notconnect)” indicates that the interface is not receiving a carrier signal, which is usually due to the cable not being plugged in.

Based on the provided information, the switch interface status indicates that the interface is down and the line protocol is also down, indicating that there is no physical layer connectivity. The most likely issue is:

B. The cable is not plugged in.

This status suggests that there is no connection on the interface, and one common reason for this is a physical connectivity issue, such as an unplugged or faulty cable. The network technician should check the physical connection between the switch interface (gigabyte ethernet 9/0) and the device hosting the shared drive. If the cable is unplugged or damaged, reseating or replacing it may resolve the issue.

choices.B: The cable is not plugged in.
